title: How to Grow Morel Mushrooms (With or Without a Kit)

steps.title: Buy a morel mushroom kit online.
steps.content: Buy a morel mushroom kit online. A morel mushroom kit is pre-packaged with spawn seed as well as a set of instructions to help you get started. A growing kit will typically cost you only a little over $30. Spawn seed is what makes the mushrooms grow and can come in several varieties such as woodchips, grain, and sawdust. [1] X Research source Using growing kit is more forgiving to beginners than doing the whole process from scratch because the spawn seed is specifically catered to helping your morel mushrooms grow.

steps.title: Prepare to plant between summer and autumn.
steps.content: Prepare to plant between summer and autumn. This will give it time to grow over the next couple of seasons. Morel mushrooms typically sprout around spring. [2] X Research source Morel mushroom hunters usually seek them out during the spring time because that’s when they grow naturally in the wild which is a useful reference point for when yours should start sprouting.

steps.title: Pick a spot in the shade that is 4x4 feet in size.
steps.content: Pick a spot in the shade that is 4x4 feet in size. It’s good to have a pre-determined portion of your garden organised for where you want to plant your mushrooms because most growing kits require a specific set of dimensions. [3] X Research source Most growing kits need 4x4 feet but check the specifications of your growing kit to make sure how much your one asks for. It’s good to pick a spot by a tree, as morel mushrooms grow more in abundance around them, especially ash and elm trees. [4] X Research source Having sandy soil will give you the best results. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Create your spawn bed with a mixture of peat moss and gypsum.
steps.content: Create your spawn bed with a mixture of peat moss and gypsum. Concoct a blend that includes 10 gallons of peat moss as well as 1 gallon of gypsum and insert it on your 4x4 garden space. The gypsum contains calcium sulfate which can help increase the size of your mushroom caps. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Adding ashes from burnt woodchips during this step will also help because it provides nutrients for your morels. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Apply the spawn seed from your growing kit.
steps.content: Apply the spawn seed from your growing kit. When you spread the spawn seed over the soil, make sure you do it evenly to give the morel mushrooms more chance to grow. The instructions that came with your kit will give you appropriate directions on how to do this. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Add hardwood chips to finish the spawn bed.
steps.content: Add hardwood chips to finish the spawn bed. You don’t have to be meticulously tidy when you do this, simply tossing it on top of the spawn bed will do the trick. [9] X Research source Much like how planting by an ash or an elm tree is useful, it is also beneficial to use woodchips from these trees as well. They will give your morel mushrooms even more incentive to grow. Woodchips can found for purchase online.

steps.title: Wait for your morel mushrooms to grow.
steps.content: Wait for your morel mushrooms to grow. Be aware this can sometimes take up to two years. The good news is that once they sprout, the morel garden can continue to provide mushrooms for several years after. [10] X Research source To guarantee that it does, remember to reapply fresh compost bi-annually. If growing your morel mushrooms doesn’t work out the first time around, don’t hesitate to try again. For most people this is a long-term endeavour.

steps.title: Collect or buy a few morel mushrooms for later use.
steps.content: Collect or buy a few morel mushrooms for later use. You will need some actual matured morel mushrooms for your home-made mixture. Only a few are necessary but they’re still vital for the process. [11] X Research source Keep them fresh by placing them in a sealable bag or box and then putting them in the fridge. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Start by boiling 1 gallon of tap-water and placing it in a food-safe container.
steps.content: Start by boiling 1 gallon of tap-water and placing it in a food-safe container. Make sure the water is filtered because the chlorine from un-filtered tap-water will falter the growth of your morel mushrooms. Making sure the container is clean is especially important in order to ensure the mixture doesn’t become contaminated.

steps.title: Add 1 tablespoon of molasses to the water.
steps.content: Add 1 tablespoon of molasses to the water. This will give it energy for your morel mushrooms to grow. It will also provide sugar to allow the spores to germinate. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a pinch of salt to prevent the spread of bacteria.
steps.content: Apply a pinch of salt to prevent the spread of bacteria. Not much is needed but it is still necessary to help avoid your morel mushrooms from getting tarnished. If you want to be specific in your measurement, use one-quarter tablespoon to be more precise.

steps.title: Insert the morel mushrooms in the mixture and stir it.
steps.content: Insert the morel mushrooms in the mixture and stir it. Make sure you only put in the spores. Just a few will be sufficient. Mushroom spores are at the top of the mushroom so all you have to do is remove the cap from the stalk. [14] X Research source If you’re unsure what to stir the mixture with, a wooden spoon is perfectly sufficient.

steps.title: Put the mixture aside and let it settle for up to 44 hours.
steps.content: Put the mixture aside and let it settle for up to 44 hours. Make sure it’s covered and out of the way. If you leave it for any longer than 44 hours the mixture runs the risk of getting bacteria. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Spread the mixture over your 4x4 feet garden space.
steps.content: Spread the mixture over your 4x4 feet garden space. Exactly like the spot that you would setup for your growing kit, pour the mixture over your sandy soil. Afterwards, cover it with hardwood chips as described in Method 1 – Step 6. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Wait and watch your morel mushrooms grow.
steps.content: Wait and watch your morel mushrooms grow. Remember that the homemade way is less reliable than the growing kit. The growing kit has mycelia spawn that has a higher chance of success. If your homemade version doesn’t work out, consider trying the growing kit. [17] X Research source
